title: How to Use Ibarra Chocolate

steps.headline: Chop the chocolate into small pieces.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to chop up four blocks of the Ibarra chocolate on a cutting board. Cut them into small pieces so they melt easily in the milk. You can add more than four blocks to the hot chocolate, but adding more may make it a bit too thick to drink. Use your discretion.

steps.headline: Warm the chocolate, milk, salt and chile in a small saucepan.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (236 ml) of the milk in a saucepan over the stove on medium heat. You can substitute with almond milk or water for a dairy free option. Add the chocolate, a dash of salt, and ⅛ teaspoon (0.625 grams) ground chile to the milk. Heat the mixture until the chocolate is melting and it is very hot, but not boiling. You may need to stir the mixture a few times to help the chocolate melt.

steps.headline: Use a whisk or hand blender to froth the mixture.
steps.description: Whisk or froth the mixture until the chocolate is completely dissolved and the top becomes foamy. You can use a hand whisk or a hand blender to do this.

steps.headline: Pour the hot chocolate in a mug.
steps.description: Once the hot chocolate is frothy, pour it into a mug. Finish the Mexican hot chocolate off by adding a dab of whipped cream and a dash of cinnamon to the top. Drink it while it is still hot.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (176 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Take a 9 x 9 metal or glass pan. Grease it with butter or cooking spray.

steps.headline: Combine the flour, cinnamon, and salt.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, stir together ½ cup (118 grams) flour, ½ teaspoon (2.5 grams) cinnamon, and ¼ teaspoon (1.25 grams) salt. Use a wooden spoon to mix all the dry ingredients together. Set the bowl aside once you have combined the ingredients together.

steps.headline: Melt the chocolate.
steps.description: Use a double boiler over medium heat to melt 1 ½ disks of Ibarra chocolate and 1 ounce (28 grams) baking chocolate. Stir the chocolate in the boiler so it melts evenly. You can make a double boiler in a pinch by placing two inches (2.54 cm) of water in a small saucepan and boiling the water. Then, place a heat resistant bowl over the saucepan and pour the chocolate in the bowl.

steps.headline: Add the butter and brown sugar to the chocolate.
steps.description: Once the chocolate has melted, add in the 6 tablespoons (90 grams) butter and ½ cup (118 ml) brown sugar. Use a wooden spoon to mix in the butter and sugar. It’s okay if the mixture is a bit grainy as long as everything is melted in the bowl.

steps.headline: Put in the beaten eggs, vanilla, and chipotle chile.
steps.description: Remove the bowl from heat. Then, drizzle in the two beaten eggs, using a whisk to combine. Add 1 teaspoon (5 grams) vanilla and 1 finely chopped chipotle chile.

steps.headline: Whisk in the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Use a whisk to add the flour, cinnamon, and salt to the bowl with the chocolate mixture. Whisk the wet and dry ingredients together until just combined. You can then pour the batter into the prepared pan.

steps.headline: Bake for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Use a toothpick to check that the brownies are cooked. Insert it into the middle of the brownie and check that just a few crumbs appear on the toothpick. This means the brownies are ready. If the toothpick comes out of the brownie very wet or covered in globs of batter, the brownies need more time to bake.

steps.headline: Serve warm.
steps.description: Take the brownies out of the oven to cool. Serve the Mexican chocolate brownies warm with a pinch of cinnamon. You can also add a scoop of dulce de leche ice cream to the brownie for extra sweetness. Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to four days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (176 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper.

steps.headline: Combine flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and cayenne.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups (473 grams) flour, 1 teaspoon (5 grams) baking soda, ¼ teaspoon (1.25 grams) salt, 1 ½ teaspoon (7.5 grams) cinnamon, and ¼ teaspoon (1.25 grams) cayenne pepper. Use a wooden spoon to mix the dry ingredients together. Set the bowl aside once they have been combined.

steps.headline: Beat together butter and sugar.
steps.description: Use a stand mixer or a hand mixer to beat together 1 cup butter (236 grams) and 1 cup (236 grams) brown sugar. Beat together until the mixture is fluffy.

steps.headline: Add the eggs and vanilla.
steps.description: Beat the two eggs into the mixture one at a time. Then, beat in 1 teaspoon (5 grams) vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Pour in the flour mixture.
steps.description: Add the flour mixture into the butter and sugar mixture. Do this one cup at a time. Mix with a wooden spoon until just combined.

steps.headline: Stir in the Ibarra chocolate chunks.
steps.description: Pour in the 12 ounces (340 grams) of Ibarra chocolate chunks and mix them into the batter until just combined.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the dough.
steps.description: Do this for at least one hour and up to one day. Making the dough cold will make it easier to place on the baking sheets. It will also ensure the cookies will turn out round and evenly shaped.

steps.headline: Place the dough on the baking sheets.
steps.description: Use a tablespoon to drop the dough on the baking sheets. You want the dough to be spaced 1 ½ inches (3.81 cm) apart and have a rounded shape.

steps.headline: Bake for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Place them in the oven and bake them until they appear golden brown but soft to the touch. If you prefer crisper cookies, bake them for 12 minutes.

steps.headline: Cool and serve.
steps.description: Take the cookies out of the oven and let them sit on the baking sheets for three minutes. Then, transfer them to cooking racks. Let the cookies cool for 5 to 10 minutes. Then, serve them. Leftover cookies can be stored in an airtight container in the fridge for up to three days.
